title: Judge rules man with Asperger's should undergo bowel surgery against wishes | Central
text:
A man in his 20s who suffers from Asperger's should undergo bowel surgery against his wishes, a judge in a specialist court has said.
Doctors said the man had ulcerative colitis and needed a operation.
But they said he had made it clear that he did not want surgery - and they questioned whether he had the mental capacity to make decisions.
Mr Justice Baker has approved a surgery plan agreed by lawyers representing doctors and the man.
He had analysed the case at a hearing in the Court of Protection - where issues relating to people who lack the mental capacity to make decisions are considered - in London on Friday.
The judge said he was satisfied that the man lacked the mental capacity to make decisions about treatment and satisfied that surgery was in the man's best interests.
He said the man could not be identified but said bosses at Nottingham University Hospitals NHS Trust had responsibility for the man's treatment and had asked him to analyse the case.
Mr Justice Baker heard evidence from medical specialists.
Doctors said the man would be sedated and only physically restrained as a last resort.
Barrister Katharine Scott had represented the hospital trust and outlined doctors' concerns.
Barrister Katie Gollop QC had represented the man after being instructed by staff at the Official Solicitor's office - which offers help to people who lack the mental capacity to take decisions.
